awd_titl_txt: Defining glucan dikinase phosphorylation of starch from multiple kingdoms
awd_abstract_narration:
Starch plays a central role in human food, agricultural animals feed, biofuels, and as an industrial feedstock. Starch from cereal crops and tubers account for 50-80% of daily caloric intake. In the U.S., 36% of corn is dedicated to animal feed and 34% is converted into biofuels. Starch is both a first-generation biofuel and a feedstock for molecular hydrogen and oil production by micro-algae. It is also an industrial feedstock for paper, textiles, adhesives, and plastics. Therefore, defining the pathways that control starch metabolism is needed in order to develop novel strategies that manipulate these pathways and satisfy the growing starch demand. This project will define molecular energy storage mechanisms from algae to plants while teaching students to test hypotheses using bioinformatics, biophysics, structural biology, cell biology, and enzymology. The broader impacts of this project may increase participation of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM, improve STEM education and educator development, help develop a diverse and globally competitive STEM workforce, and increase public scientific literacy and engagement with science technology.

Reversible phosphorylation of starch glucose is the only known natural modification of starch, and it directly influences starch hydration, crystallinity, freeze-thaw stability, viscosity, and transparency, which are all central to industrial applications. Starch producing organisms possess either one or two glucan dikinases that phosphorylate starch glucose. Their activity is critical for the production and utilization of starch in vivo. Despite their key biological role, little is known regarding the physical and functional basis for glucan dikinase action. To define the biology and biochemistry of glucan dikinases, the researchers focus on green plants which possess two glucan dikinases. Further, there is currently no means to harness their unique activity. This research will develop methods to utilize glucan dikinases by focusing on algal systems that possess only one glucan dikinase. The project combines state-of-the-art biophysical approaches with biochemistry, cell biology, algal genetics, and glucan analysis to define the function, dynamics, structures, and regulation of glucan dikinases. The objectives of this research are to: (I) define the molecular enzymology of glucan dikinases, (II) determine structural dynamics and crystal structures of glucan dikinases, and (III) elucidate the biological function of algal glucan phosphorylation.

This award was co-funded by the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, and the Rules of Life Venture Fund.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Harnessing Designer Starches: Engineering Phosphorylation for Industrial and Food Applications

Starch is an essential biomolecule with widespread applications in human nutrition, agriculture, and industrial manufacturing. It serves as a major food source, a key ingredient in pharmaceuticals, and an important material in biofuels and biodegradable products. However, natural starch often lacks the properties required for specific industrial uses. This NSF-funded research focused on understanding and manipulating starch phosphorylation, a natural process that alters the functionality of starch molecules. By studying the enzymes responsible for phosphorylation, this project provided foundational knowledge and practical strategies for developing designer starches—starches with tailored properties optimized for food processing, drug delivery, textiles, and sustainable energy applications.

At the heart of this research was the study of glucan dikinases, enzymes that introduce phosphate groups to starch molecules, influencing their solubility, digestibility, and structural stability. These enzymes play a central role in how plants break down and utilize starch, but their potential extends beyond natural plant metabolism. By controlling phosphorylation patterns, starch can be engineered to exhibit properties such as improved thickening ability, enhanced freeze-thaw stability, and optimized resistance to enzymatic digestion. This project combined biochemical analysis, structural biology, and enzymatic engineering to unravel the mechanisms of starch phosphorylation and apply them to industrial and food science challenges.

Scientific Breakthroughs and Intellectual Merit

Starch is a carbohydrate that serves as the primary energy storage molecule for glucose in plants and is a crucial component of the human diet, animal feed, and multiple industrial products. Its versatility makes it essential in food processing, pharmaceuticals, textiles, and even biofuel production. However, natural starch often lacks the precise functional properties required for specific applications, making it necessary to modify its structure—particularly through phosphorylation—to enhance its stability, digestibility, and performance in different industries.

One of the major scientific achievements of this research was a detailed characterization of two key enzymes that are critical in starch metabolism: Glucan, Water Dikinase (GWD) and Phosphoglucan, Water Dikinase (PWD). These enzymes sequentially add phosphate to starch at specific positions on glucose. Through biochemical assays and kinetic analysis, this project provided a molecular-level understanding of how these enzymes regulate starch breakdown and modification. The addition of phosphate disrupts starch’s crystalline structure, making it more accessible for enzymatic digestion. Our discoveries not only advance the field’s understanding of starch metabolism in plants but also provides a framework for engineering starches with precise functional properties.

A second major outcome of the research was the structural characterization of GWD and PWD. Using X-ray crystallography and advanced biophysical techniques, we determined the three-dimensional structures of these enzymes, shedding light on how they interact with starch molecules. These structural insights led to the successful engineering of modified enzyme variants, allowing for controlled phosphorylation patterns. By fine-tuning phosphorylation, it is possible to customize starch properties for various industrial applications, including food stabilizers, biodegradable plastics, and pharmaceutical excipients.

By manipulating phosphorylation, researchers can modify starch viscosity, thermal stability, and resistance to degradation. Our work provides a foundation for industries looking to replace synthetic additives with naturally modified starches, reducing reliance on chemical stabilizers while maintaining product quality and functionality.

Broader Impacts: Industrial and Societal Applications

The findings from this research have broad implications across multiple industries. In the food industry where phosphorylated starches offer improved functionality for a variety of products:

  • Thickening Agents: Starches with controlled phosphorylation levels exhibit enhanced water-binding capacity.
  • Stability in Frozen Foods: Phosphorylation reduces ice crystal formation, leading to better texture and quality retention in frozen products.
  • Baked Goods with Customizable Texture: Adjusting phosphorylation levels allows for precise control over crumb structure, which impacts baked goods.
  • Resistant Starches for Dietary Benefits: Increasing phosphorylation can enhance resistant starch content, which improves gut health and reduces glycemic response, making it beneficial for diabetic-friendly and high-fiber diets.

Beyond food applications, phosphorylated starches hold promise in the pharmaceutical industry. Certain modified starches can be used in controlled-release drug formulations, ensuring that medications dissolve at a regulated rate, improving drug absorption and effectiveness. Additionally, starch-based excipients with specific phosphorylation patterns can enhance stability and bioavailability of active pharmaceutical ingredients.

In the paper and textile industries, starch phosphorylation improves fiber strength, water resistance, and processing efficiency. Our work also has implications to sustainable biofuel production, as optimizing starch phosphorylation can enhance starch breakdown efficiency, leading to higher bioethanol yields. Furthermore, the ability to engineer starch properties makes it a valuable alternative for biodegradable packaging materials, reducing reliance on petroleum-based plastics.

Education, Workforce Development, and Outreach

This project played a significant role in training the next generation of scientists and engineers. Over 20 undergraduate and graduate students received hands-on research experience in biochemical assays, structural biology, and starch engineering. Many of these students co-authored peer-reviewed publications and successfully transitioned into careers in academia, biotechnology, and industrial research. Additionally, five graduate students participated in this work.
